title: More area players earn invitations to NFL camps
body_text:
NFL
ODU, W&M products gain camp invites
More rookies from around the area received interest from NFL teams, whether it was signing as an undrafted free agent to a 90-man roster and getting a rookie minicamp tryout.
Old Dominion tight end Pat Conroy is going to the Las Vegas Raiders, offensive lineman Santana Saunders to the Indianapolis Colts.
Former ODU player Jordan Bly, who competed in 2024 for Gardner-Webb, is going to the New York Giants.
Former Virginia Tech wide receiver Da’Quan Felton, who played for Churchland High, Norfolk State and Virginia Tech, also signed with the Giants.
Ex-William & Mary star Hollis Mathis earned a rookie minicamp invitation with the Pittsburgh Steelers on Monday. Mathis, a Pittsburgh native, is one of just two players in the history of college football to total 1,000 career yards passing, rushing and receiving. As a senior, Mathis led W&M with 52 receptions for 602 yards and three touchdowns.
Ex-W&M safety Marcus Barnes, a second-team All-CAA pick last season for W&M, earned a minicamp invite with the Cincinnati Bengals.
Former James Madison defensive lineman Khairi Manns was invited to the Giants’ minicamp, and ex-JMU cornerback Jordan Taylor was invited to the Raiders’ minicamp.
Former JMU linebacker Jailin Walker, who helped Indiana reach the College Football Playoff, signed with the Raiders.
COLLEGE BASEBALL
Captains outslug Hampden-Sydney
Christopher Newport (20-17) scored 10 runs in the sixth inning and went on to win 21-11 at Hampden-Sydney (18-21). The Captains had 19 hits — all singles and doubles — and went ahead 15-10 with their double-digit inning.
Sam Benedict was 4 for 5 with three doubles, six RBIs and two runs. Aaron Maxie drove in four runs and was 2 for 3, Scott Crosson scored four runs, and Creston Saunders was 2 for 4 with two runs and three RBIs.
Mitchell Mortensen held the Tigers to one run in the final three innings, striking out five and walking none.
Apprentice edges VPCC
Apprentice (23-14) edged Virginia Peninsula Community College 7-6, rallying for three runs in the bottom of the seventh at War Memorial Stadium. Hunter Johnson’s two-run homer tied the score for the Builders, and Landon Turner scored the eventual winning run on Nate Yeary’s fielder’s-choice grounder to second.
Justin Bradshaw pitched a scoreless sixth for the victory, and Jaeden Anderson earned his sixth save by working the seventh.
For the Gators (13-31), Aidan Feather scored twice, drove in three runs and hit a homer.
Tribe players gain CAA awards
William & Mary freshman right-hander Zach Boyd was named the Coastal Athletic Association Pitcher of the Week, and infielder Jamie Laskofski repeated as the CAA Rookie of the Week.
Boyd threw the first shutout by a Tribe pitcher since 2013, limiting Stony Brook to three hits and no walks over seven innings and fanning five in a 15-0 win Saturday.
Laskofski hit .533 (8 for 15) with a double, two triples, a homer, six runs and eight RBIs in W&M’s 4-0 week.
COLLEGE SOFTBALL
Ex-Spartan Higa named Player of Week
Howard senior Kenna Higa earned the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference’s Player of the Week honor.
Higa, from Honolulu, helped the Bison secure the regular-season title with a series sweep at Norfolk State, batting .583 (7 of 12) with six runs, five RBIs, three doubles, two stolen bases and a homer against her former school.
This season, she is second in the MEAC in batting average, slugging percentage and OPS (on-base plus slugging percentage).
COLLEGE MEN’S BASKETBALL
German forward commits to UVA
Virginia has gained a commitment from 6-foot-11 German forward Johann Grünloh, according to the Field of 68’s Jeff Goodman, for Ryan Odom’s first season as the Cavaliers’ coach.
Grünloh, 19, plays for SC Rasta Vechta in the top level of pro club basketball in Germany. he has started every game and has averaged 8.5 points, 5.5 rebounds and 1.8 blocks per game while shooting 35 percent from 3-point range.
NSU signs two transfers
Norfolk State coach Robert Jones signed 6-8 former Saint Peter’s forward Jaquel Morris, who averaged 3.3 points, 4.4 rebounds, and 1.1 blocks per contest in 18 games for the Jersey City, New Jersey-based Peacocks last season.
The Spartans also signed former UNC Wilmington guard Elijah Jamison, a 6-3 player from Louisburg, North Carolina. He averaged nine points per game last season.
Prior to his time at UNCW, Jamison excelled for two years while competing in the Horizon League with Milwaukee. He averaged 8.9 points, 2.9 rebounds, and 2.7 points per game as a sophomore after picking up Horizon League All-Freshman Team honors while averaging 7.6 points, 2.7 rebounds and 1.6 assists.
Ex-Churchland player commits to JMU
James Madison landed a commitment from Winthrop transfer Paul Jones III, a former Churchland High standout who grew up in Suffolk. He finished prep school at Combine Academy.
The 6-4 guard was on the Big South All-Freshman team for Winthrop. He averaged 7.8 points and 2.9 rebounds.
WOMEN’S BASKETBALL
W&M’s Nascimento to play for Brazil
Bella Nascimento, who led William & Mary to its first CAA championship and its first NCAA Tournament victory, will be on the Brazilian national team for exhibitions this week against the WNBA’s Chicago Sky and Indiana Fever.
COLLEGE TRACK AND FIELD
NSU men set two school records at Penn Relays
At the Penn Relays in Philadelphia, Norfolk State senior Gidion Sigei broke his own school and MEAC record in the 10,000 meters, finishing in 29 minutes, 7.85 seconds.
Also, the Spartans’ 4×400-meter relay of Donovan Terry, Tafari Bishop, Kendrick Winfield and Vincent Bond Jr. set a school record by finishing fifth in 3:05.07.
HU athletes thrive at Penn Relays
Hampton University’s women’s 4×400 relay of Jordan Mozie, Dejah Grant, Arriah Gilmer and Kayla Spencer finished seventh in the Championship of America race with a 3:42.43. That grouping ran 3:37.46 in the qualifying rounds Friday to make Saturday’s final.
Grant also ran in the 400 hurdles, where she finished seventh in 58.01 and won her heat.
Junior Damali Williams finished eighth in the discus throw at 52.07 meters (170 feet, 10 inches).
COLLEGE MEN’S GOLF
UVA edges UNC for ACC championship
Virginia won its first ACC championship, beating North Carolina 3-2 to emerge atop an eight-team match-play field. The Cavaliers had been the runner-up five times.
Three of the five matches went to the 18th hole, including the final pairing, in which Bryan Lee held off Maxwell Ford to clinch the victory. Deven Patel and Paul Chang were UVA’s other victors.
After 13 holes, Lee was down by two and chipped in for birdie on 14 to begin an epic comeback. He won the eighth hole on a 25-foot birdie putt. The chip-in began a stretch where he won four of his last five holes.
UVA will learn its NCAA assignment at 1 p.m. Wednesday during the pairings show on the Golf Channel.
COLLEGE TENNIS
Hampton legend Screen to make ITA Hall of Fame
Longtime Hampton University tennis coach Dr. Robert Screen, who died in 2015, was announced by the Intercollegiate Tennis Association as one of four members of the first Posthumous Class of 2025 for the ITA Men’s Tennis Hall of Fame.
Screen, the chair of Hampton’s Department of Communicative Sciences and Disorders for 50 years, totaled 1,068 victories in 40 years of coaching men’s tennis, and the Pirates won the NCAA Division II championship in 1976 and ’89.
He is joined by coach Jim Poling from Army and Peter Scott of Flagler, plus player Peter Doohan from Arkansas.
CNU women seeded first, men’s second for C2C tourney at home
Pairings for this weekend’s Coast-To-Coast Athletic Conference championships in Newport News were released, with the school matchups — but not the seedings — being the same. All matches are at Christopher Newport’s Eyre Tennis Center.
In the women’s semifinals at 10 a.m. Saturday, top-seeded Christopher Newport will face No. 4 Salisbury, while No. 2 UC Santa Cruz will take on No. 3 Mary Washington.
CNU, the defending champion, is ranked 30th in Division III by the Intercollegiate Tennis Association computer. UC Santa Cruz is 41st, Mary Washington 61st and Salisbury out of the top 75.
In the men’s semis at 2 p.m. Saturday, second-seeded CNU will face third-seeded Salisbury, while top-seeded Mary Washington takes on No. 4 UC Santa Cruz.
In the national rankings, Mary Washington is 16th, CNU 26th, Salisbury 29th and UC Santa Cruz 62nd.
Sunday, the women’s final will be held at 10 a.m., followed by the men’s championship match at 2 p.m.
The C2C does not have automatic bids into the NCAA championships, though the tournament winners figure to be under strong consideration.
CNU’s Hansen, Maury grad Felts take C2C awards
CNU’s Eddy Porsmyr Hansen and Mary Washington’s Addison Felts were named the men’s and women’s C2C Players of the Week, respectively.
Hansen, a senior, won with Gabe Smith on doubles line 2 and at singles line 3 to help the Captains edge Salisbury 4-3 Saturday.Felts, a sophomore from Norfolk’s Maury High, won at No. 1 singles and No. 1 doubles in both of UMW’s matches — a victory over Virginia Wesleyan and a loss to No. 20 Swarthmore.
COLLEGE WOMEN’S LACROSSE
CNU to host conference semifinal Wednesday
Christopher Newport (7-10) received the No. 2 seed in the Coast-To-Coast Athletic Conference tourney and will play host to No. 3 Mary Washington (11-6) at 4 p.m. Wednesday in a semifinal at Jennings Family Stadium.
The winner of that game will play Saturday for the title against the winner of Wednesday’s 1 p.m. semifinal pitting No. 4 Warren Wilson (5-7) at No. 1 Salisbury (12-4). The higher seed will host that contest.
